title: Electra (1962) w. Irene Papas  spoken Greek, EN, FR, SP subs
description:
Electra (1962) by Euripides

starring Irene Papas
Directed by  Mihalis Kakogiannis 

Original Greek with easy to read English, French and Spanish subtitles 
selectable  from your VLC player

Nominated for 3 Oscars. Another 11 wins & 12 nominations

run time: 1 hr 52 minutes 

IMDb number:  tt0055950

IMDb description:

   This excellent adaptation by Michael Cacoyannis (whose name varies in 
spelling over his long career of doing Greek drama) of the famous tragedy by 
Euripides garnered him his first international success and an award at the 
1962 Cannes Film Festival. Irene Papas plays Electra, the daughter of King 
Agamemnon and sister of Orestes, caught up in an uncontrollable need for 
revenge. After the king returns from the battlefield, Clytemnestra (his wife) 
joins with her lover in murdering the hapless ruler while he bathes. Orestes 
is sent away immediately, and Electra is left to simmer in her growing hatred 
of her mother until one day, she and Orestes manage to get together and hatch 
a scheme to avenge Agamemnon's death.
--
my notes on the new recode

  I have gone back to this drama several times lately just for the look of it.

When I did I saw that the subs were not showing and no one ever 
pointed it out.  This recode is to correct that.  Use your VLC player to 
select the subtitles from English, French, or Spanish.  A fourth item listed 
is not modern Greek.  It is of the kind of captions for hearing impaired in 
English and appears in white rather than the easy to read yellow. 

  The black and white style resembles the post war work of Rosselini's Open 
City.  Papas appears with here hair shorn as an outcast and has the hard look 
of someone betrayed. 

  These treatments of ancient Greek drama are all too rare and they are a 
trademark of Cacoyannis throughout his career.  Look for Iphegenia as well.  

  As an added observation it is interesting to see this Electra and then the 
Iphigenia with Papas first in the role of Electra at a young age and then as 
the mother of Iphegenia in the next generation of the Greek story.
  
I got the dvd of Electra locally and it is the best source around that I 
know of.  The DVD is currently available at the usual sources.  Please encourage your library to acquire it in order that more viewers learn from and enjoy the history of the drama.

New Notes written February 5 2016
